title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON (AP) — This was not basketball. This was theater, and the hardwood floor of The Summit was Shaquille O’Neal’s stage. In a performance for the ages, the Orlando Magic’s colossal center delivered a historic 45-point, 16-rebound masterpiece, single-handedly wrestling a 96-95 victory from the Houston Rockets in a heart-stopping finish.

From the opening tip, it was clear Shaq was operating on a different plane. He was an unstoppable force, a wrecking ball in the paint who dunked, muscled, and willed his way to a scoring tally that left the Rockets’ defense—and the stat sheet—in tatters. While Hakeem Olajuwon, his legendary counterpart, fought valiantly for 26 points, he was merely a supporting actor in O’Neal’s one-man show. The Magic’s offense was a simple, devastating equation: get the ball to Shaq.

Yet, Houston refused to yield. Clyde Drexler chipped in 19 points, and the Rockets chipped away, turning what looked like a coronation into a white-knuckle brawl. The final seconds were a blur of tension, with the home crowd roaring for a stop. But when the final horn sounded, the scoreboard told the story of a single, dominant force. The Magic had escaped, but this was not a team victory. It was a testament.

On this night, Shaquille O’Neal didn’t just beat the Houston Rockets. He overwhelmed them. He authored a line so monumental, so overwhelmingly dominant, that it will be etched into the annals of the game, a reminder of the sheer, awe-inspiring power of a player at the absolute peak of his powers.
